entry.title: Postdoc form
entry.content:
Page-1

  1. E-mail: cr7or9@163.com
  2. Name; Jinzhuo Wang
  3. Current position and affilation: 5th-year Ph.D candidate at the department of EECS, Peking University, China
  4. Seeking position: Postdoc
  5. Years of research/working experince in computer security: None
  6. Years of research/working experince in machine learning: 5 years

Page-2:

  1. Years of research/working experince in deep learning: 4 Years
  2. Years of experince in programming and in which programming languages: 8 years; C/C++, Python, Matlab
  3. Link to your webpage: www.wangjinzhuo.com
  4. Link to your CV: www.wangjinzhuo.com/pdf/cv.pdf
  5. Link to your github repo: github.com/wangjinzhuo
  6. Provide the name, postion, and contact info of three of your recommenders (one per line):
    1) Wen Gao, Professor at EECS, Peking University, wgao@pku.edu.cn;
    2) Wenmin Wang, Professor at ECE, Peking University, wangwm@ece.pku.edu.cn;
    3) Huifang Sun, Research/Technical Staff at MERL, hsun@merl.com.
  7. Describe your research interests and why would you like to apply for a position:
    My research interests focus on deep learning, artificial intelligence and computer vision. I believe the Postdoc position is an excellent choice for enhancing my research career. More importantly, the Prof.Song’s current deep learning project attracts me a lot, especially her recent published papers on ICLR 2017. I believe my background on deep learning and artificial intelligence are appropriate for this position.

Page-3:

  1. Mention three of your most favorite papers/write-ups and why:
    1) The pyramid match kernel: discriminative classification with set of features. K.Grauman and T.Darrell. In ICCV 2005.
    Reason: A simple but elegant algorithm motivated my first paper.
    2) Imagenet classification with deep convolutional neural networks. A.Krizhevsky et.al. In NIPS 2012.
    Reason: This paper shows a good example for deep learning researchers: It can never be too specific in implementation details. Also, the proposed ReLU activation function gradually shows its importance to train a deep neural network and motivates many followers such pReLU, eLU, peLU.
    3) Master the game of Go with deep neural networks and tree search. D.Silver et.al. Nature 2016.
    Reason: As a Go player who have learnt Go for more than ten years, it shocks me a lot. On the other hand, this paper shows the combination strength of excellent models and inspires me to explore the combination potential of deep learning with other techniques in AI and machine learning.
  2. Mention three of my papers that you find most relevant to your interests and why:
    1) Making neural programming architectures generalize via recursion. In ICLR 2017.
    Reason: Applying classical algorithm to neural networks is always a good choice for deep learning researchers.
    2) Delving into transferable adversarial examples and black-box attacks. In ICLR 2017.
    Reason: Although GAN has been hot for a few years, this paper still gives me new and important insight about adversarial examples.
    3) Adversarial examples for generative models. https://arxiv.org/pdf/1702.06832.pdf
    Reason: A good paper that provides detailed instructions to generate adversarial examples, which supports the possibilities to fool a well-trained deep neural network.
  3. Describe your system building experince. What is the biggest project that you have done? How long did you work on it? How many lines of code did you write for it? Provide any additional details for the project to illustrate your system building experince:
    It is the DANN work that was published in NIPS 2016. I worked on it for about 2 months. Codes are around 600 lines. That was the first time I developed algorithms with torch7. Considering the large video datasets, it was a challenging system building experience to perform model investigation for a deep neural architecture.
  4. Provide a bullet list of your notable experince/projects that are of relevance:
    1) An action recognition framework that is built around a novel DANN architecture, which levearges the advantages of both CNN and RNN. This paper is published in NIPS 2016.
    2) I wrote a computer Go system that utilizes deep neural networks and domain knowledge, which is published in AAAI 2017.
    3) Two transformation-based prediction works are accepted by ACM Multimedia 2017. One is to predict future frames from a single frame, and the other is from a short video clip.
    4) My current project is a universal differentiable layer, which is responsible for collaborative learning with knowledge sharing. Unlike GAN, this layer can be deployed among multiple models, and enjoys a non-zero-sum game with a win-win process.
  5. How would you like to describe your work ethics and philosophy:
    Teamwork, motivation and focus. I always believe that learning is like rowing upstream: not to advance is to drop back.
  6. Mention three of your favorite books and why:
    1) The romance of three kingdoms. An amazing long novel with magificant description of war, marvelous strategy of intrigue and a variety of characters, making many so-called “epic fictions” cast into the shade.
    2) Malice: A Mystery. Actually I am addicted to almost all the fictions of Keigo Hlgashino, the writer of “Malice: A Mystery”. This book shows me something about human nature.
    3) The legendary swordman. Same as above, I love all the 14 books written by Jinyong, a real swordman. I am fascinated by the world of martial arts.
  7. Anything else you would like to mention about yourself:

entry.title: Collaborative learing with knowledge sharing
entry.content:
Recently arise many successful deep architectures that are carefully designed for tasks in artificial intelligence, computer vision, natural language processing and speech recognition. In such cases, one model (or deep architecture) trained with one task (specific input and output) can learn corresponding knowledge. Different models can learn task-specific knowledge. On the other hand, the target tasks share many relevant properties (such as image classification and semantic segmentation), the learnt knowledge that exists among the model is expected to have something in common. This paper aim at levering such information to achieve model assistance, and consequently improving the performance of involved models.

In particular, we introduce a new learnable module called collaborative learning layer (CLL) that is responsible to mix the learnt knowledge of involved models and extract relevant knowledge to achieve assistance. The core structure of our proposed module is built around a differentiable mutual knowledge base (MKB), which preserves and updates the mutual knowledge. The MKB recieves encoded knowledge of individual models and mixed them into a universal representation. We show how to train CLL along with involved models and the use of CLL can improve the performance of involved models.

The CLL is very flexible and can be deployed with many settings. First, it can be inserted among multiple architectures, which means it is able to help model assistance. Second, multiple CLLs can be used to enhance the performance of Collaborative learning. Third, CLL can be applied with tasks that are the same, relevant, and even non-relevant.

entry.title: Properties of neural networks
entry.content:
Intriguing properties of neural networks – https://arxiv.org/pdf/1312.6199.pdf

  1. It suggests that it is the space, rather than the individual units, that contains the semantic information in the high layers of neural networks.
  2. It suggests that the learnt input-output mappings by deep neural networks are fairly discontinuous. That means it is easy to fool a well trained neural networks.

See also in https://arxiv.org/pdf/1412.6572.pdf where the authors show it is easy to generate adversarial examples which are close to the original ones but are misclassified by neural networks.

entry.title: Conference attendance report of AAAI-2017
entry.content:
AAAI 2017 took place in San Francisco and lasted for 5 days.

First time attending to AAAI, a coverall AI conference which accepts papers of every aspect of AI research.

A great talk given by Prof. Grauman about learning from unlabeled videos http://www.cs.utexas.edu/%7Egrauman/slides/grauman-AAAI2017.pdf, which I think is close to recent popular attention model.

entry.title: Conference attendance report of NIPS 2016
entry.content:
Glad to attend NIPS 2016 in Barcelona, a beautiful costal city in Spain. It is lucky for a football fan to join a party in Nou Camp.

There are many famous researchers including LeCun, Schmidhuber and other yound research scientists in DeepMind and OpenAI. They give talks, introduce posts, communicate and share ideas. I like such atmosphere.

An impressive work is “Learning to learn by gradient descent by gradient descent” by M.Andrychowicz et.al. in DeepMind. I read its previous version in arxiv and asked the authors at poster room in the first evening. You can not imagine how popular the DeepMind’s paper was. I waited for almost half of an hour to ask the author several questions.

entry.title: Smartcity competition
entry.content:
The finals of Smartcity competition for chinese graduates raised the curtain in Wuhan University, July.

Our team participated in the task of video anomaly detection. Our algorithm is based on an unsupervised analysis of trajectory features of normal videos, as the number of anomaly videos available is rather small. We first build a mix model composed of normal bases, and calculate the distance of test videos to the learnt bases to make judgement.

Our final performance ranked at the second position. It is a not bad result.
